{{Infobox language |name=Kelabit |region=Borneo |speakers={{sigfig|4640|1}} |date=2000–2011 |ref=e18 |familycolor=Austronesian |fam2=[[Malayo-Polynesian languages|Malayo-Polynesian]] |fam3=[[North Bornean languages|North Bornean]] |fam4=[[North Sarawakan languages|North Sarawakan]] |fam5=[[Apo Duat languages|Apo Duat]] |iso3=kzi |glotto=kela1258 |glottorefname=Kelabit }} [[File:Languages of Kalimantan.svg|thumb|'''Kelabit''' among the languages of Kalimantan (orange #27, top)]] '''Kelabit''' is one of the most remote languages of [[Borneo]], on the [[Sarawak]]–[[Kalimantan]] border. It is spoken by one of the smallest ethnicities in Borneo, the [[Kelabit people]]. ==Phonology== Vowels are {{IPA|/ə, a, e, i, o, u/}}. All consonants but the aspirated voiced stops are lengthened after stressed {{IPA|/ə/}}. Stress generally occurs on the penultimate syllable. Kelabit is notable for having "a typologically rare series of [[Aspirated_consonant#Voiced_stop|true voiced aspirate]]s" (that is, not [[breathy voice]]/murmured consonants; for some speakers they are [[prevoiced consonant|prevoiced]]) along with [[voiced consonant|modally voiced]] and [[tenuis consonant]]s but without an accompanying series of [[aspirated consonant|voiceless aspirates]]. It is the only language known to have voiced aspirates or murmured consonants without also having voiceless aspirated consonants, a situation that has been reconstructed for [[Proto-Indo-European language|Proto-Indo-European]].[[Robert Blust]], 1974. A double counter-universal in Kelabit. ''Papers in Linguistics'' :309-24. (See [[glottalic theory]].) {| class="wikitable" |+Kelabit consonants[[Robert Blust]], 2006, "The Origin of the Kelabit Voiced Aspirates: A Historical Hypothesis Revisited", ''Oceanic Linguistics'' 45:311 |- !colspan=2| ![[Bilabial consonant|Bilabial]] ![[Dental consonant|Dental]] ![[Alveolar consonant|Alveolar]] ![[Postalveolar consonant|Postalveolar]]
/[[Palatal consonant|Palatal]] ![[Velar consonant|Velar]] ![[Glottal consonant|Glottal]] |-align=center !colspan=2|[[Nasal consonant|Nasal]] |{{IPA link|m}} | |{{IPA link|n}} | |{{IPA link|ŋ}} | |-align=center !rowspan=3|[[Stop consonant|Stop]] !{{small|[[Tenuis consonant|tenuis]]}} |{{IPA link|p}} |{{IPA link|t̪}} | | |{{IPA link|k}} |{{IPA link|ʔ}} |-align=center !{{small|[[modally voiced]]}} |{{IPA link|b}} | |{{IPA link|d|d͇}} |({{IPA link|dʒ}}) |{{IPA link|ɡ}} | |-align=center !{{small|[[aspirated voiced]]
/[[prevoiced]]}} |{{IPA|b͡pʰ ~ b͡p}} | |colspan=2|{{IPA|d͇͡t͇ʃʰ ~ d͇͡t͇}} |{{IPA|ɡ͡kʰ ~ ɡ͡k}} | |-align=center !colspan=2|[[Fricative consonant|Fricative]] | | |{{IPA link|s}} | | |{{IPA link|h}} |-align=center !colspan=2|[[Sonorant]] | | |{{IPA link|l}}, {{IPA link|ɾ|ɾ͇}} |{{IPA link|j}} |{{IPA link|w}} | |} At the end of a word, {{IPA|/t/}} is pronounced {{IPA|[θ]}}. For some speakers, {{IPA|/d͇͡t͇ʰ/}} is affricated; in neighboring [[Lun Dayeh language|Lun Dayeh]], the reflex of this consonant is an unaspirated affricate {{IPA|[d͡tʃ]}}. {{IPA|/dʒ/}} is rare, and is not attested from all dialects. The flap is alveolar. It's not clear if {{IPA|/n/}} and the other coronal sonorants are alveolar like {{IPA|/d/}} or dental like {{IPA|/t/}}. The aspirated voiced series only occurs intervocalicly, and may have arisen from geminate consonants. They are at least impressionistically twice as long as other stops. They vary with {{IPA|/b d͇ ɡ/}} under suffixation, with {{IPA|/b͡pʰ d͇͡t͇ʰ ɡ͡kʰ/}} occurring where other consonants would be allophonically geminated: *{{IPA|/təb͡pʰəŋ/ [ˈtəb͡pʰəŋ]}} 'to fell' > {{IPA|/təbəŋ-ən/ [təˈbəŋːən]}} 'fell it!' *{{IPA|/kətəd/ [ˈkətːəd]}} 'back (n)' > {{IPA|/kətəd͇͡t͇ʰ-ən/ [kəˈtəd͇͡t͇ʰən]}} 'to be left behind' There are several arguments for analyzing the aspirated voiced consonants as segments rather than as consonant clusters: *There are no (other) clusters allowed in the language. Some languages allow only geminate consonants as clusters, but there are no (other) phonemic geminates in Kelabit. In some related languages, such as [[Ida'an language|Ida'an]], the reflexes of these sounds clearly do behave as clusters. *The syllable break occurs before the consonants (that is, {{IPA|[a.bpa]}}, and not in the middle ({{IPA|[ab.pa]}}), which is the behaviour of consonant clusters (including geminates) in related languages that allow them. {{IPA|/i, u/}} lower to {{IPA|[ɪ, ʊ]}} before any non-glottal coda consonant. They do not lower before the aspirated voiced consonants, again suggesting they are not consonant clusters. The aspirated voiced series does not appear in all dialects of Kelabit or Lun Dayeh: {|class="wikitable" |+Reflexes in Kelabit and Lun Dayeh dialects[[Robert Blust]], 2006, "The Origin of the Kelabit Voiced Aspirates: A Historical Hypothesis Revisited", ''Oceanic Linguistics'' 45:311 |- |{{IPA|b͡p⁽ʰ⁾}}||{{IPA|d͡t⁽ʰ⁾}}||{{IPA|ɡ͡k⁽ʰ⁾}}||Bario, Pa' Omor, Long Lellang, Lun Dayeh: Long Semado |- |{{IPA|p}}||{{IPA|t}}||{{IPA|k}}||Pa' Mada |- |{{IPA|p}}||{{IPA|tʃ}}||{{IPA|k}}||Long Terawan Tring |- |{{IPA|p}}||{{IPA|s}}||{{IPA|k}}||Batu Patung, Pa' Dalih, Sa'ban |- |{{IPA|f}}||{{IPA|tʃ}}||{{IPA|k}}||Lun Dayeh: Long Pala |- |{{IPA|f}}||{{IPA|s}}||{{IPA|k}}||Long Napir, Long Seridan |} ==References== {{reflist}} == Bibliography == * Asmah Haji Omar (1983). ''Oceanic Linguistics'' 45 (2): 311-338. * Blust, Robert (2016). Kelabit-Lun Dayeh Phonology, with Special Reference to the Voiced Aspirates. {{Tone|date=July 2011}} {{Cleanup|date=July 2011}} The '''Khakha Rajputs''' of [[Azad Kashmir]], [[Pakistan]] are clan of [[Muslim Rajputs]]<ref>''Culture and Political History of Kashmir'' by [[Prithivi Nath Kaul Bamzai]], MD Publ. Ltd., 1994, p669</ref> who have inhabited the Kashmiri region since the 13th century after the conquer of [[Janjua|Janjua warlord]] Raja Khakha of the region of Upper Jhelum Valley of Kashmir.
==History== The Khakhas, a warrior tribe that ruled western Punjab since the 13th century.<ref>''History of Mediaeval Hindu India'' by Chintaman Vinayak Vaidya, Cosmo Publ. 1979, p129</ref> Historians have queried whether the Khakha name is a derivative distortion of the word Khatri rather than an actual name of the tribe:
{{quote|Historian Pt Har Gopal Kaur feels that the word Brahman got corrupted to make Bamba and the word Khatri to yield Khakha (author - I have no opinion on what these clan names are a corruption of. However, knowing the languages of the area, I have no doubt that these are corruptions of words beginning with B and with K respectively.<ref>Parvéz Dewân's Jammû, Kashmîr, and Ladâkh: Travel, Trekking, Culture, History, Wildlife, Almost Everything By Parvez Dewan Edition: illustrated Published by Manas Publications, 2004 Item notes: v. 1 Original from the University of Michigan Page 423</ref>}}
==Mughal period== The Khakha Rajputs played an important part in the history of Kashmir by creating alliances with other Kashmiri tribes against many powerful rulers, such as the [[Mughal Empire|Mughal]] [[Akbar|Emperor Akbar]]. The Khakha warlords allied with Kashmiri Emperor Yakub Shah against Akbar's amry at the battle of Bulyasa and were victorious.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20060321074329/http://www.kashmir-information.com/Baharistan/chapter8.html]</ref>{{better source|date=October 2015}}
==Sikh Empire== During the Sikh conquest of Kashmir, the Khakha Rajputs, and also the [[Bomba Dynasty|Bhamba]] tribe, occasionally ventured into the valley on looting expeditions and thus annoyed the Sikh invaders.<ref name="Kashmir' 1994, p637"/>
It is recorded, that upon a British Officer's visit to Kashmir in 1822, he had to return from Uri as the Khakha chief would not allow him to pass.<ref name="Kashmir' 1994, p637">''Culture and Political History of Kashmir'' by Prithivi Nath Kaul Bamzai, MD Publ. Ltd., 1994, p637</ref>
The Khakhas began to intensify their raids in consequence to the weakening Sikh power. Eventually, when Maharaja [[Gulab Singh]] assumed rulership of Kashmir, he managed to drive back the Khakhas with great difficulty. But knowing the unrelenting fierce reputation of the rebellious Khakhas, he immediately installed strong [[garrisons]] in the forts guarding the passes.<ref>''Culture and Political History of Kashmir'' by Prithivi Nath Kaul Bamzai, MD Publ. Ltd., 1994, p637, p669, p670</ref>
Despite facing the best of the Sikh power to subdue them, they still enjoyed a highly privileged position, paying little if any taxes, openly wearing arms and defying orders where possible.<ref name="Jammu 1987, p4">''History of Operations in Jammu & Kashmir, 1947-48'' by Sri Nandan Prasad, Dharm Pal, Govt. of India 1987, p4</ref>
==Ancestral title and reputation== The Khakhas continue their tradition of recording their genealogy.<ref>''Kashmiris Fight for Freedom'' by Muhammad Yusuf Saraf, Ferozson 1977, p77</ref>
Their fierce, often predatorial raids during the Sikh age earned them a localised legend, that mothers would tell their children "..the Khakhas are coming..." to frighten them.<ref>''Kashmiris Fight for Freedom'' by Muhammad Yusuf Saraf, Ferozson 1977, p78</ref>

Lose your will into [[Allah|His]]
[[Assertiveness|Self-assertion]] is [[blasphemy]]
Shun the Self and merge into [[God|Him]]{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}}}} ==Shrine of Makhdum Bilawal== [[File:Dadu_District_Sindh.JPG|thumb|right|200px|Shrine of Makhdum Bilawal]] His [[shrine]] is at 'Baghban' near the town of [[Dadu, Pakistan|Dadu]] [[Sindh]], [[Pakistan]]. According to the article of Nadeem Wagan, the [[mosque]] at his [[tomb]] was constructed by one of his devotees [[Sardar]] Mahboob Khan Wagan (Chief Sardar of Wagan Tribe). == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == {{Sindhi Sufis}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bilawal, Makhdoom}} [[Category:Sufi poets]] [[Category:Sindhi people]] [[Category:Samma tribes]] [[Category:Sindhi-language poets]] [[Category:Sufism in Sindh]] [[Category:Year of birth uncertain]] [[Category:1451 births]] [[Category:1523 deaths]]

A '''marriage of state''' is a diplomatic marriage or union between two members of different [[nation-state]]s or internally, between two power blocs, usually in authoritarian societies and is a practice which dates back into pre-history, as far back as early [[Ancient Greece|Grecian]] cultures in [[Western world|western society]], and of similar antiquity in other civilizations. The fable of [[Helen of Troy]] may be the best known pre-historic tale reporting an incidence of surrendering a female member of a ruling line to gain peace or shore up alliances of state between nation-states headed by small oligarchies or acknowledged royalty.{{citation needed|date=March 2014}}
== Europe == [[File:Lodewijk XIV-Marriage.jpg|thumb|''The marriage of the [[Louis, Duke of Burgundy|Duke of Burgundy]] to [[Marie Adélaïde of Savoy]] on December 7, 1697 by [[Antoine Dieu]]]]
While the contemporary Western ideal sees marriage as a unique bond between two people who are in love, families in which heredity is central to power or inheritance (such as royal families) often see marriage in a different light. There are often political or other non-romantic functions that must be served, and the relative wealth and power of the potential spouses are considered. Marriage for political, economic, or diplomatic reasons was the pattern for centuries among European rulers.<ref name="fleming" >{{ cite journal | last =Fleming | first =Patricia H. |date=June 1973 | title =The Politics of Marriage Among Non-Catholic European Royalty | journal =[[Current Anthropology]] | volume =14 | issue =3 | pages =231–249 | doi =10.1086/201323 }}</ref>
Careful selection of a spouse was important to maintain the royal status of a family: depending on the law of the land in question, if a prince or king was to marry a commoner who had no royal blood, even if the first-born was acknowledged as a son of a sovereign, he might not be able to claim any of the royal status of his father.<ref name="fleming" />
Traditionally, many factors were important in the arranging of royal marriages. One such factor was the size of the tracts of land that the other royal family governed or controlled.<ref name="fleming" /> Another, related factor was the stability of the control exerted over that territory: when there is territorial instability in a royal family, other royals will be less inclined to marry into that family.<ref name="fleming" /> Another factor was [[political alliance]]: marriage was an important way to bind together royal families and "their countries during peace and war" and could justify many important political decisions.<ref name="fleming" />
== Importance of religion == Religion has always been closely tied to political affairs and continues to be today in many countries. Religious considerations were often important in marriages among royal families, particularly in lands where there was an established or [[official religion]]. When a royal family was prepared to negotiate or arrange the marriage of one of its children, it was extremely important to have a prospective spouse who followed the same religion or, at the very least, that the spouse be willing to convert before the wedding. In non-[[Catholic Church|Catholic]] royal families, there were few things worse than marrying a person who was a Catholic.<ref name="fleming" /> Some countries barred from accession to the throne any person who married a Catholic, as in the British [[Act of Settlement 1701]]. When a [[Protestantism|Protestant]] prince converted to Catholicism, he risked being disowned by his family,<ref name="fleming" /> and often being barred from the throne himself. Some of these laws are still in force, centuries after the conclusion of Europe's [[Catholicism and the wars of religion|Wars of Religion]].
Roman Catholic countries had similar laws and strictures. [[History of France#Early Modern France (1453–1789)|France]], for example, effectively barred non-Catholics from the throne. Even if the law did not strictly prohibit marrying non-Catholic royalty, [[French Wars of Religion|political situations]] and [[French Wars of Religion#Henry IV|popular sentiment]] were frequently sufficient to dissuade princes from so doing.
== Rulers' marriages ==
===Elizabeth I===
Contrary to what some historians have said about her elusiveness when in marriage negotiations with suitors or their representatives, [[Queen Elizabeth I]] was known to be straightforward in her various courtships.<ref name="doran mm">{{cite book|last1=Doran|first1=Susan|title=Monarchy & Matrimony: The courtships of Elizabeth I|date=1996|publisher=Routledge|location=London|isbn=0-415-11969-3}}</ref> In 1565, when in the midst of the [[House of Habsburg|Habsburg]] matrimonial project, Elizabeth promptly dismissed the rival French suit of their fourteen-year-old king, stating she would have to be ten years younger to consider it.<ref name="doran mm" /> Furthermore, in addition to concerns about religion, financial arrangements, and security, Elizabeth also maintained that she could not marry anyone whom she had not seen in person, perhaps as a result of her father's own displeasure and divorce of [[Anne of Cleves]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Warnicke|first1=Retha|title=Why Elizabeth I Never Married|journal=History Review|date=2010|issue=67|pages=15–20}}</ref> The emphasis on religion, national security, and securing the line of succession in all of Elizabeth's marriage negotiations demonstrate the emphasis placed on the political importance of marriages of state during this period. Although some of her contemporaries hoped she would find solace in marriage, procreation was still considered the primary purpose of royal marriage.
In March 1565, Elizabeth told her Spanish ambassador, [[Diego Guzmán de Silva]]: :If I could appoint such a successor to the Crown as would please me and the country, I would not marry, as it is a thing for which I have never had any inclination. My subjects, however press me so that I cannot help myself or take the other course, which is a very difficult one. There is a strong idea in the world that a woman cannot live unless she is married, or at all events that is she refrains from marriage she does so for some bad reason....But what can we do?<ref>{{cite book|last1=Levin|first1=Carole|title=The Heart and Stomach of a King|date=2013|publisher=University of Pennsylvania Press|location=Philadelphia|isbn=978-0-8122-2240-1|page=49|edition=2}}</ref>
Thus, Elizabeth appeared to personally believe that a woman should reasonably be able to remain single. However, she continued to engage in marriage negotiations for decades because of the expectations of her role as monarch. Although she herself had little inclination to marry, she understood the limitations of her power and therefore seriously considered marriage on numerous occasion at the behest of councillors.
The Habsburg marriage negotiations revolving around the marriage of [[Queen Elizabeth I]] to [[Charles II, Archduke of Austria|Archduke Charles]] show the way marriage was often negotiated in royal families. The first phase began in 1559, with the initiative for a matrimonial alliance between England and Austria.<ref name="doran" >{{ cite journal | last =Doran | first =Susan |date=October 1989| title =Religion and Politics at the Court of Elizabeth I: The Habsburg Marriage Negotiations of 1559-1567 | journal =[[The English Historical Review]] | volume =104 | issue =413 | pages =908–926 | doi =10.1093/ehr/CIV.413.908 }}</ref> However, the first phase was a failure and, the people of England were relieved to the extent that they feared a foreign ruler coming into their country.<ref name="doran" /> Negotiations were re-opened with some difficulty in 1563 by the English.<ref name="doran mm" /> This was in part due to Charles' search for a wife elsewhere, the lack of permanent diplomatic links between Austria and England, and because of [[Ferdinand I, Holy Roman Emperor|Emperor Ferdinand]]'s distrust of Elizabeth for her refusal of his son's suit in 1559. However, [[Sir William Cecil]] was interested in the match and began work on a marriage negotiation.<ref name="doran" /> While the first set of negotiations were uncertain, the second round of negotiations gathered stronger support in England for the suit and went on for several years.
Both sides hoped to gain from a marital alliance. In England, the negotiations were a key element to Elizabeth's foreign policy and intended to protect the country's commercial interests and political security against the French-Scottish alliance.<ref name="doran mm" /> Austria also hoped to gain in similar ways from a political alliance and possibly bring Catholicism back to England. However, English support was partly due to the fact that the English had been deliberately misled to believe that Charles would be willing to convert to Protestantism and in the end, the archduke's Catholicism and refusal to come to England before finalizing a betrothal proved too difficult to overcome and the suit dissolved. These negotiations, nevertheless, illustrate how support and opposition ebbed and flowed over the course of time, and how issues like religion, which seemed to be resolvable at the outset, could ultimately doom an otherwise promising proposal.
===Napoleon===
[[Napoleon]], as emperor, gave out kingdoms and female relatives with equal largesse to favored Marshals and general officers.
===United Kingdom=== Through most of recorded history state marriages were also common at lesser levels of nobility, and many a lesser marriage of state was consummated and bargained over during all of the Middle Ages and through the middle of the twentieth-century in western society, and the old forms still hold sway in many other cultural contexts today. One famous example of a marriage of state for lesser reasons was that of [[George II of Great Britain]]'s parents. The Princess Sophia's dowry included properties assuring an income of 100,000 thalers annually, which led to George Louis, [[Duchy of Brunswick-Lüneburg|Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg]] (the future [[George I of Great Britain]]), marrying his first cousin [[Sophia Dorothea of Celle]]—when both were pressed into the arrangement by his mother— and that German ducal dynastic move accidentally gave the couple the inside track on the Protestant thrones of England, Scotland and Ireland (and later, those of the United Kingdom and Ireland).
==See also== * [[Arranged marriage]] * [[Heqin]] – a similar practice in Ancient China * [[Royal intermarriage]]

plus 5 made for TV movies between 1999 and 2005 |}} '''''North of 60''''' is a 1990s [[Television in Canada|Canadian television]] drama depicting life in the sub-[[Arctic]] northern boreal forest (north of [[60th parallel north|60° north]] [[latitude]], hence the title). It first aired on [[CBC Television]] in 1992 and was [[television syndication|syndicated]] around the world. It is set in the fictional community of [[Lynx River]], a primarily Native-run town depicted as being in the [[Dehcho Region]], [[Northwest Territories]]. Most of the characters were [[Dene]]. Some non-native characters had important roles: the restaurant/motel owner, the band manager, the nurse and (during the show's first season) the town's main [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police|RCMP]] officer. The show explored themes of Native poverty, alcoholism, cultural preservation, conflict over land settlements, and natural resource exploitation. Originally somewhat light-hearted (a CBC response to the very successful ''[[Northern Exposure]]'' on CBS), it quickly became a more ponderous dramatic series. ==Casting== Starring in the series were [[Tina Keeper]] as RCMP Constable, later Corporal, Michelle Kenidi, Tracey Cook as Sarah Birkett (nurse during first year), [[Tom Jackson (actor)|Tom Jackson]] as Peter Kenidi (band chief in first year, Michelle's brother), [[Gordon Tootoosis]] as Albert Golo (bootlegger, then band chief), Dakota House as Trevor 'Teevee' Tenia (teen trouble-maker, then band chief), Lubomir Mykytiuk as Gerry Kisilenko (restaurant/motel owner/justice of the peace), [[Jimmy Herman]] as Joe Gomba (elder) and [[Simon R. Baker]] as Charlie Muskrat. [[Adam Beach]] and [[Tantoo Cardinal]] also starred. Elsie Tsa Che ([[Wilma Pelly]]) was a fan favorite, playing Teevee's grandmother, a community elder. [[John Oliver (actor)|John Oliver]] led the cast as Corporal Eric Olsen during the show's first two seasons and entered into an off-screen relationship with co-star Keeper; he left the show when his relationship with Keeper soured. Keeper subsequently became the show's lead actor for the remainder of its run. Oliver was replaced by [[Robert Bockstael (actor)|Robert Bockstael]] as Corporal Brian Fletcher, who was replaced later by Peter Kelly Gaudreault as Constable James Harper. One of the stars was [[Michael Horse]], as Andrew One Sky, previously best known for his portrayal of Tonto in the 1981 film ''[[The Legend of the Lone Ranger]]''. ===List of characters=== {{expand list|date=July 2012}} {|class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Character ! Actor ! Seasons ! Baker]] | 4-6 | A young boy whom Michelle Kenidi takes into her home when his mother is unable to properly care for him. |- | Sylvie LeBret | [[Michelle Thrush]] | 1,5-6 | Peter's love interest in later seasons |- | James Harper | Peter Kelly Gaudreault | 5-6 | RCMP officer, who replaces Brian Fletcher |} ==Series== The series ran weekly until 1998. From 1999 through 2005 it was followed by five made-for-TV films featuring various members of the show's recurring cast. These films include ''In The Blue Ground'' (1999), ''Trial by Fire'' (2000), ''Dream Storm'' (2001), ''Another Country'' (2003), and ''Distant Drumming'' (2005). A soundtrack album was produced in 1994, including theme music, background music and songs performed by Tom Jackson and others. The series was filmed in [[Bragg Creek]], [[Alberta]]. == External links == {{portal|Television in Canada}} * {{IMDb title|0106087|North of 60}} * [http://www.tvarchive.ca/database/17943/north_of_60/details/ North of 60 at the TVArchive] [[Category:First Nations television series]] [[Category:CBC Television shows]] [[Category:Dene culture]] [[Category:1990s Canadian drama television series]] [[Category:1992 Canadian television series debuts]] [[Category:1997 Canadian television series endings]] [[Category:Television shows set in the Northwest Territories]] [[Category:Television series by Alliance Atlantis]] [[Category:Television series by Entertainment One]]

{{Infobox language |name=Pacific Northwest English |region= [[Northwestern United States]] ([[Oregon]], [[Northern California]] and [[Washington (state)|Washington]]) |speakers2= |familycolor=Indo-European |fam2 = [[Germanic languages|Germanic]] |fam3 = [[West Germanic languages|West Germanic]] |fam4 = [[North Sea Germanic]] |fam5 = [[Anglo-Frisian languages|Anglo-Frisian]] |fam6 = [[Anglic languages|Anglic]] |fam7 = [[English language|English]] |fam8 = [[North American English]] |fam9 = [[American English]] |fam10 = [[Western American English]] |isoexception=dialect }} '''Pacific Northwest English''' (also known, in American linguistics, as '''Northwest English'''){{citation |mode=cs1 |last=Riebold |first=John M. |date=2014 |url=http://students.washington.edu/riebold/files/Riebold%202014%20-%20Language%20Change%20Isn't%20Only%20Skin%20Deep.pdf#page=7 |title=Language Change Isn't Only Skin Deep: Inter-Ethnic Contact and the Spread of Innovation in the Northwest |work=Cascadia Workshop in Sociolinguistics 1 at University of Victoria |publisher=University of Washington |page=7 |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151023021458/http://students.washington.edu/riebold/files/Riebold%202014%20-%20Language%20Change%20Isn%27t%20Only%20Skin%20Deep.pdf#page=7 |archive-date=2015-10-23 |df= }} is a variety of [[North American English]] spoken in the [[U.S. states]] of [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington]] and [[Oregon]], sometimes also including [[Idaho]] and the [[Canadian province]] of [[British Columbia]].{{citation |mode=cs1 |last=Riebold |first=John M. |date=2012 |url=http://students.washington.edu/riebold/files/Riebold%202012%20-%20Please%20Merge%20Ahead.pdf#page=2 |title=Please Merge Ahead: The Vowel Space of Pacific Northwestern English |work=Northwest Linguistics Conference 28 |publisher=University of Washington |page=2 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150928152327/http://students.washington.edu/riebold/files/Riebold%202012%20-%20Please%20Merge%20Ahead.pdf#page=2 |archive-date=2015-09-28 |dead-url=yes |df= }} Current studies remain inconclusive about whether Pacific Northwest English is a dialect of its own, separate from [[Western American English]] or even [[California English]] or [[Standard Canadian English]],{{harvcoltxt|Ward|2003|p=87}}: "lexical studies have suggested that the Northwest in particular forms a unique dialect area (Reed 1957, Carver 1987, Wolfram and Shilling-Estes 1998). Yet the phonological studies that could in many ways reinforce what the lexical studies propose have so far been less confident in their predictions". with which it shares its major phonological features.{{harvcoltxt|Ward|2003|pp=43–45}} The dialect region contains a highly diverse and mobile population, which is reflected in the historical and continuing development of the variety. ==History== The linguistic traits that flourish throughout the Pacific Northwest attest to a [[culture]] that transcends boundaries. Historically, this hearkens back to the early years of [[Colonialism|colonial expansion]] by the British and Americans, when the entire region was considered a single area and people of all different mother tongues and nationalities used Chinook Jargon (along with English and French) to communicate with each other. Until the [[Oregon Treaty]] of 1846, it was identified as being either [[Oregon Country]] (by the Americans) or [[Columbia District|Columbia]] (by the British).{{citation |mode=cs1 |last=Meinig |first=Donald W. |author-link=Donald W. Meinig |title=The Great Columbia Plain |orig-year=1st pub. 1968 |edition=Weyerhaeuser Environmental Classic |year=1995 |publisher=University of Washington Press |isbn=978-0-295-97485-9 |page=104}} As a result of the 1897 [[Klondike Gold Rush]], the culture of the Pacific Northwest expanded northward into [[Yukon]] and [[Alaska]], carried along by the thousands of people who were attracted to the gold fields in the north. Today, the English variety common to this shared culture can be heard by people from [[Eugene, Oregon]] to [[Fairbanks, Alaska]].{{citation |mode=cs1 |last=Lang |first=George |title=Making Wawa: The Genesis of Chinook Jargon |publisher=UBC Press |year=2008 |location=Vancouver |pages=especially 127–128 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oTYXs35aTFkC&pg=PA127 |isbn=978-0-7748-1526-0}}{{Dubious|Issues|date=July 2011}} Linguists immediately after World War{{nbsp}}II tended to find few patterns unique to the Western region, as among other things, Chinook Jargon and other "slang words" (despite Chinook Jargon being an actual separate language in and of itself, individual words from it like "salt chuck", "muckamuck", "siwash" and "tyee" were and still are used in Pacific Northwest English) were pushed away in favour of having a "proper, clean" dialect.[[#refWolframWard2005|Wolfram and Ward 2006, pg. 140]] Several decades later, linguists began noticing emerging characteristics of Pacific Northwest English, although it remains close to the [[General American|standard American accent]]. ==Phonology== [[File:Pacific Northwest English vowel space.PNG|right|600px|thumb|The Pacific Northwest English vowel space. Based on TELSUR data from Labov et al. The {{IPA|/ɑ/}} and {{IPA|/ɔ/}} are indistinguishable in the F1/F2 means for three speakers from Vancouver, British Columbia, two speakers from Seattle, and three from Portland, Oregon]] ===Commonalities with both Canada and California=== * Pacific Northwest English has all the [[merger (phonology)|phonological merger]]s typical of North American English and, more specifically, all the mergers typical of [[Western American English]], including the [[cot–caught merger|''cot–caught'' merger]]. * Younger speakers of Pacific Northwest English also show features of the [[Canadian Shift|Canadian/California Vowel Shift]], which move front vowels through a lowering of the tongue: ** {{IPA|/æ/}} is lowered toward almost {{IPA|[a]}}; {{IPA|/ɛ/}} toward almost {{IPA|[æ]}}; and {{IPA|/ɪ/}} toward almost {{IPA|[ɛ]}}. Therefore, among younger speakers, ''hick'' can sound like ''heck'', ''heck'' like ''hack'', and ''hack'' like ''hock''.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} ** {{IPA|/ɑ/}} is backed and sometimes rounded to become {{IPA|[ɒ]}}. Most Pacific Northwest speakers have undergone the [[Cot–caught merger|''cot–caught'' merger]]. A notable exception occurs with some speakers born before roughly the end of World War{{nbsp}}II. ===Commonalities with Canada=== These commonalities are shared with Canada and the North Central United States which includes the Minnesota accent. * Traditional and older speakers may show certain [[vowel]]s, such as {{IPA|[oʊ]}} as in ''boat'' and {{IPA|[eɪ]}} as in ''bait'', with qualities much closer to [[monophthong]]s than [[diphthong]]s as in the rest of the country. * There are also conditional raising processes of open front vowels. These processes are often more extreme than in Canada and the North Central United States. ** Before the [[velar nasal]] {{IPA|[ŋ]}}, {{IPA|/æ/}} becomes {{IPA|[e]}}. This change makes for [[minimal pair]]s such as ''rang'' and ''rain'', both having the same vowel {{IPA|[e]}}, differing from ''rang'' {{IPA|[ræŋ]}} in other varieties of English. ** Among some speakers in Portland and southern Oregon, {{IPA|/æ/}} is sometimes raised and diphthongized to {{IPA|[eə]}} or {{IPA|[ɪə]}} before the nasal consonants {{IPA|[m]}} and {{IPA|[n]}}. This is typical throughout the country. ** {{IPA|/ɛ/}}, and, in the northern Pacific Northwest, {{IPA|/æ/}}, become {{IPA|[eɪ]}} before the [[voiced velar plosive]] {{IPA|/ɡ/}}: ''egg'' and ''leg'' are pronounced to rhyme with ''plague'' and ''vague'', a feature shared by many northern Midwestern dialects and with the [[Utah]] accent. In addition, sometimes bag will be pronounced ''bayg''. ===Commonalities with California=== * Back vowels of the California Shift: The Canadian/California Shift developing in Pacific Northwest English also includes these additional features only reminiscent of California English, but not Canadian English (especially among working-class young-adult females):{{harvcoltxt|Ward|2003|p=93}} ** The close central rounded vowel {{IPA|[ʉ]}} or close back unrounded vowel {{IPA|[ɯ]}} for {{IPA|/u/}}, is found in Portland and some areas of Southern Oregon, but is generally not found further north, where the vowel remains the close back rounded {{IPA|[u]}}.{{Dubious|date=August 2008}} ** In speakers born around the 1960s, there is a tendency to move the tongue forward in the first element of the diphthong {{IPAc-en|oʊ}}. This is reminiscent also of Midland, Mid-Atlantic, and Southern U.S. English.{{citation |mode=cs1 |last=Conn |first=Jeff |date=2002 |title=An investigation into the western dialect of Portland Oregon |others=Paper presented at [[New Ways of Analyzing Variation|NWAV]] 31, Stanford, California |url=http://www.pds.pdx.edu/Publications/NWAV31.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151121011733/http://www.pds.pdx.edu/Publications/NWAV31.htm |archive-date=2015-11-21 |dead-url=no |df= }} This fronting does not appear before {{IPA|/m/}} and {{IPA|/n/}}, for example, in the word ''home''.{{harvcoltxt|Ward|2003|p=44}} * Absence of [[Canadian raising]]: For most speakers, both {{IPA|/aɪ/}} and {{IPA|/aʊ/}} remain lax before voiceless [[obstruent]]s, although some variation has been reported. This likens the Pacific Northwest accent with Californian accents, and contrasts it with Canadian and some other American dialects (such as [[Philadelphia English]]). ===Miscellaneous characteristics=== * Some speakers perceive or produce the pairs {{IPA|/ɛn/}} and {{IPA|/ɪn/}} close to each other,[[#refLabovAshBoberg2006|Labov, Ash, Boberg 2006]] for example, resulting in a [[Phonological history of English high front vowels#Pin–pen merger|merger between ''pen'' and ''pin'']], most notably in [[Eugene, Oregon]] and [[Spokane, Washington]].Labov et al. 2006. p. 68. * Consonant phonology is more conservative, as with other varieties of English. ==Words and phrases== Pacific Northwest English adopted some words from [[Chinook Jargon]], as before the beginning of the 1900s essentially the entire population was at least slightly bilingual in the language.{{cn|date=August 2018}} There are also several terms of English origin that originated in or are distinct to the region.{{Citation needed|date=November 2017}} * ''Duff:'' [[forest litter]]{{citation |mode=cs1 |title=A brief history of words unique to the Pacific Northwest |publisher=KUOW |date=2014-12-23 |url=http://kuow.org/post/brief-history-words-unique-northwest |last=Raftery |first=Isolde |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150921233420/http://kuow.org/post/brief-history-words-unique-northwest |archive-date=2015-09-21 |quote=Duff = The decaying vegetable matter, especially needles and cones, on a forest floor.
[[Fish wheel]] = A wheel with nets, put in a stream to catch fish; sometimes used to help fish over a dam or waterfall. |deadurl=yes |df= }} * ''(High) muckamuck:'' an important person or person of authority, usually a pompous one (from Chinook Jargon, where it means "eats a lot; much food") * ''Potlatch:'' a [[potluck]] (from Chinook Jargon, where it means "give, a gift") * ''Rig:'' any vehicle, including car, truck, or [[Sport utility vehicle|{{abbr|SUV|sports utility vehicle}}]]{{citation |mode=cs1 |url=http://1027kord.com/what-do-you-call-your-vehicle-we-love-our-kord-rig-photos/ |title=What Do You Call Your Vehicle? |date=2012-10-22 |publisher=[[KORD-FM]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150912040729/http://1027kord.com/what-do-you-call-your-vehicle-we-love-our-kord-rig-photos/ |archive-date=2015-09-12 |dead-url=no |last=DeLange |first=Greg |location=Richland, Washington |quote=This causes confusion sometimes when one of us calls everything with four wheels a ‘rig’ |df= }} * ''Salt chuck:'' the ocean (from Chinook Jargon, where it means "salt water" or "the ocean"; today used on the radio). * ''Spendy:'' expensive{{citation |mode=cs1 |url=https://www.pbs.org/speak/seatosea/americanvarieties/pacificnorthwest/ |title=Do You Speak American? § Pacific Northwest |publisher=PBS |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150723233207/http://www.pbs.org/speak/seatosea/americanvarieties/pacificnorthwest/ |archive-date=2015-07-23 |dead-url=no |quote=As Portlanders continue to front their back vowels, they will continue to '''go to the coast''' (''geow'' to the ''ceowst''), not the beach or the shore, as well as to microbrews, used clothing stores (where the clothes are not too '''spendy''' (expensive), bookstores (''bik''‑stores) and c''o''ffee sh''o''ps (both words pronounced with the same vowel). |df= }} * ''[[Sunbreak]]:'' a passage of sunlight in the clouds during dark, rainy winters (typical west of the [[Cascade Mountains]]){{citation |mode=cs1 |date=2013-02-08 |title=Solar neighborhood projects shine in 'sunbreak' Seattle |first=Reid |last=Champagne |newspaper=The Seattle Times |url=http://www.seattletimes.com/business/real-estate/solar-neighborhood-projects-shine-in-lsquosunbreakrsquo-seattle/ |access-date=2013-05-29 |quote={{bracket|I}}n this part of the world . . . sunshine is more frequently reported as ‘sunbreaks’. |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151121011841/http://www.seattletimes.com/business/real-estate/solar-neighborhood-projects-shine-in-lsquosunbreakrsquo-seattle/ |archive-date=2015-11-21 {{For|the general condition, global perspectives|Precarity}} '''Precarious work''' is a term that critics of [[globalization]] use to describe non-standard [[employment]] that is poorly paid, insecure, unprotected, and cannot support a household.<ref name=FudgeOwens2006p3-28>{{cite book |first1=Judy |last1=Fudge |first2=Rosemary |last2=Owens |chapter=Precarious work, women and the new economy: the challenge to legal norms |pages=3–28 |editor-first1=Judy |editor-last1=Fudge |editor-first2=Rosemary |editor-last2=Owens |year=2006 |title=Precarious work, women and the new economy: the challenge to legal norms |series=Onati International Series in Law and Society |publisher=Hart Publishing |location=Oxford |isbn=9781841136165}}</ref> From this perspective, [[globalization]], the shift from the [[manufacturing sector]] to the [[service sector]], and the spread of [[information technology]] have created a new [[economy]] which demands flexibility in the workplace, resulting in the decline of the standard employment relationship, particularly for women.<ref name=volsko2011>{{cite book|title=Managing the Margins: Gender, Citizenship and the International Regulation of Precarious Employment|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|date=2011|last=Volsko|first=Leah F.|isbn=9780191614521}}</ref><ref name=kalleberg2011>{{cite book|author=Arne L. Kalleberg|title=Good Jobs, Bad Jobs: The Rise of Polarized and Precarious Employment Systems in the United States, 1970s-2000s|year=2011|publisher=[[Russell Sage Foundation]]|isbn=978-1-61044-747-8|url=https://www.russellsage.org/publications/good-jobs-bad-jobs}}</ref> The characterization of [[temporary work]] as "precarious" is disputed by scholars and [[Entrepreneurship|entrepreneurs]] who see these changes as positive for individual workers.<ref name=arthur2001>{{cite book|title=The Boundaryless Career: A New Employment Principle for a New Organizational Era|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|editor1-last=Arthur|editor1-first=Michael B.|editor2-last=Rousseau|editor2-first=Denise M.|date=2001|isbn=9780199762118}}</ref><ref name=vallas2012>{{cite journal|title=Dualism, Job Polarization, and the Social Construction of Precarious Work|author1-last=Vallas|author1-first=Steven|author2-last=Prener|author2-first=Christopher|journal=Work and Occupations|date=November 1, 2012|volume=39|issue=4|pages=331-353|doi=10.1177/0730888412456027}}</ref>
==Contrast with regular and temporary employment==
The term "precarious work" is frequently associated with the following types of employment: "[[part-time]] employment, [[self-employment]], fixed-term work, [[temporary work]], [[wikt:Special:Search/on call|on-call]] work, [[Homeworker|home-based workers]], and [[telecommuting]]."<ref name=FudgeOwens2006p3-28/><ref name=gaapw>{{Cite journal | last = International Metalworkers' Federation | first = Central Committee 2007 | title = Global action against precarious work | journal = Metal World | issue = 1 | pages = 18–21 | publisher = Global Union Research Network - GURN | date = 2007 | url = http://www.industriall-union.org/sites/default/files/migration/imf/RelatedFiles/07032015092779/WEB_spotlight_0107-2.pdf | archive-url = https://archive.is/20140610010449/http://www.gurn.info/en/topics/precarious-work/trade-unions-and-precarious-work/imf-global-action-against-precarious-work/view | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 2014-06-10 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} </ref> Scholars and critics who use the term "precarious work" contrast it with the "standard employment relationship," which is the term they use to describe full-time, continuous employment where the employee works on their employer’s premises or under the employer's supervision, under an employment contract of indefinite duration, with standardized working hours/weeks and social benefits such as [[pensions]], [[unemployment]] benefits, and medical coverage.<ref name=kalleberg2000>{{cite journal|title=Bad jobs in America: Standard and nonstandard employment relations and job quality in the United States|journal=American Sociological Review|date=2000|volume=65|number=2|pages=256-278|last1=Kalleberg|first1=Arne L.|last2=Reskin|first2=Barbara F.|last3=Hudson|first3=Ken|doi=10.2307/2657440}}</ref> This "standard employment relationship" emerged after [[World War II]], as men who completed their education would go on to work full-time for one employer their entire lives until their [[retirement]] at the age of 65.<ref name=FudgeOwens2006p3-28/> It did not typically describe women in the same time period, who would only work temporarily until they got married and had children, at which time they would withdraw from the workforce.<ref name=volsko2011 />
[[Image:We Can Do It!.jpg|thumb|right|"[[We Can Do It!]]" US wartime poster (often mistaken for [[Rosie the Riveter]])]]
While many different kinds of [[part-time]] or limited-term jobs can be [[temporary work|temporary]], critics of [[globalization]] use the term "precarious" strictly to describe work that is uncertain, unpredictable, or offers little to no control over working hours or conditions.<ref name=kalleberg2009>{{cite journal|title=Precarious Work, Insecure Workers: Employment Relations in Transition|journal=American Sociological Review|last=Kalleberg|first=Arne L.|date=February 1, 2009|volume=74|number=1|pages=1-22|doi=10.1177/000312240907400101}}</ref><ref name=conversation>{{cite web|url=https://theconversation.com/precarious-employment-is-rising-rapidly-among-men-new-research-94821|title=Precarious employment is rising rapidly among men: new research|date=April 12, 2018|author1-last=Cassells|author1-first=Rebecca|author2-last=Duncan|author2-first=Alan|author3-last=Mavisakalyan|author3-first=Astghik|author4-last=Phillimore|author4-first=John|author5-last=Tarverdi|author5-first=Yashar|work=The Conversation|access-date=July 2, 2018}}</ref> This characterization has been challenged by scholars focused on the [[autonomy|agency]] that [[temporary work]] affords individual workers.<ref name=arthur2001 /> However, many studies promoting individual [[autonomy|agency]] focus on highly-educated and skilled [[Knowledge worker|knowledge workers]], rather than all kinds of [[temporary work|temporary workers]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Gurus, Hired Guns, and Warm Bodies: Itinerant Experts in a Knowledge Economy|publisher=Princeton University Press|date=2011|last1=Barley|first1=Stephen R.|last2=Kunda|first2=Gideon|isbn=9781400841271}}</ref><ref name=vallas2012 />
==Regulation==
While increased flexibility in the [[marketplace]] and in employment relationships has created new opportunities for regulation, regulation intended explicitly to remediate precarious work often produces mixed results.<ref name=campbell2016>{{cite journal|title=Precarious work and precarious workers: Towards an improved conceptualisation|journal=The Economic and Labour Relations Review|last1=Campbell|first1=Iain|last2=Price|first2=Robin|date=September 1, 2016|volume=27|issue=3|pages=314-322|doi=10.1177/1035304616652074}}.</ref> The [[International Labour Organization]] (ILO) has developed standards for atypical and precarious employment, including the 1994 Convention Concerning Part-time Work, the 1996 Convention Concerning Home Work, and the 1999 "Decent Work" initiative.<ref name=vosko2006>{{cite book |first1=Leah F. |last1=Vosko |chapter=Gender, precarious work, and the international labour code: the ghost in the ILO closet |pages=53–76 |editor-first1=Judy |editor-last1=Fudge |editor-first2=Rosemary |editor-last2=Owens |year=2006 |title=Precarious work, women and the new economy: the challenge to legal norms |series=Onati International Series in Law and Society |publisher=Hart Publishing |location=Oxford |isbn=9781841136165}}</ref> == See also == * [[Flexicurity]] * [[Gig economy]] * [[Labour market flexibility]] * [[Precariat]] * [[Workforce casualisation]] * [[Zero-hour contract]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== * Andranik S. Tangian "[http://www.boeckler.de/pdf/p_wsi_diskp_153_e.pdf Is flexible work precarious? A study based on the 4th European survey of working conditions 2005]", WSI-Diskussionspapier Nr. 153, [[Hans-Böckler-Stiftung]] June 2007 * * Sonia McKay, Steve Jefferys, Anna Paraksevopoulou, Janoj Keles, "[http://ec.europa.eu/social/BlobServlet?docId=7925&langId=en Study on Precarious work and social rights]" Working Lives Research Institute, [[London Metropolitan University]], April 2012

{{Infobox organization | name = Redneck Revolt | logo = Redneck Revolt logo.jpg | logo_size = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | predecessor = John Brown Gun Club | merged = | successor = | formation = {{start date and age|2009}} | founding_location = [[Kansas]], United States | extinction = | merger = | type = | status = | purpose = | headquarters = | location = United States | methods = [[Direct action]], firearms and first aid training, [[open carry]], outreach, food and clothing programs, [[community gardens]], [[needle exchange]]s, [[potluck]]s, educational events, protests, security and medical assistance at protests | fields = | membership = | membership_year = | language = | owner = | sec_gen = | leader_title = | leader_name = | leader_title2 = | leader_name2 = | leader_title3 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | key_people = | main_organ = | parent_organization = | subsidiaries = | secessions = | affiliations = | slogan = | mission = | website = {{URL|redneckrevolt.org|RedneckRevolt.org}} | remarks = | formerly = | footnotes = }} {{American socialism}} '''Redneck Revolt''' is an American [[far-left politics|far-left]] group{{cite web|first=Stephanie|last=March|title=Antifa: The hard left's call to arms|work=[[ABC Online]]|date=March 18, 2018|accessdate=August 9, 2018|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-01-15/redneck-revolt-and-the-hard-lefts-call-to-arms/9303758}}{{cite web|first=Serven Smith|last=Ruth|title=Kessler, Redneck Revolt agree to end paramilitary activity in city|work=[[The Daily Progress]]|date=July 12, 2018|accessdate=August 9, 2018|url=https://www.dailyprogress.com/news/local/kessler-redneck-revolt-agree-to-end-paramilitary-activity-in-city/article_7c191edc-85eb-11e8-ae77-cbe9f0302dc4.html}} that organizes predominantly among white [[Working class in the United States|working-class people]]. The group supports [[Gun politics in the United States|gun rights]] and members often [[open carry|openly carry]] firearms. Its political positions are [[Anti-capitalism|anti-capitalist]], [[Anti-racism|anti-racist]] and [[Anti-fascism|anti-fascist]]. Founded in [[Kansas]] in 2009, members were present at several [[protests against Donald Trump]] and against the [[far-right politics in the United States|far right]] in 2017. ==Background== Redneck Revolt was founded in 2009,{{sfn|Bray|2017|p=119}} in part in response to the perceived contradictions of the [[Tea Party movement]], as an offshoot of the '''John Brown Gun Club''', a firearms training and community defense project that was itself founded in [[Lawrence, Kansas]] in 2004.{{sfn|Bray|2017|p=119}}{{sfn|Van Sant|2018|p=1}} Founding member Dave Strano was previously part of the Kansas Mutual Aid Network, which was involved in organizing [[2004 Republican National Convention protest activity|protests against the Republican National Convention]] in 2004, in relation to which he and others began to train with firearms and engage in [[Second Amendment]] advocacy.{{sfn|Van Sant|2018|p=1}}{{cite web|url=https://www.indyweek.com/indyweek/they-hate-racists-they-love-assault-rifles-meet-redneck-revolt/Content?oid=13262567|title=They Hate Racists. They Love Assault Rifles. Meet Redneck Revolt.|date=April 11, 2018|accessdate=August 17, 2018|work=[[Indy Week]]|first=Jordan|last=Green}} In the early 2000s, John Brown Gun Club members operated anti-racist stalls at [[gun shows in the United States|gun shows]] in Kansas.{{cite web|url=https://www.opendemocracy.net/levi-van-sant/redneck-revolt-radical-responses-to-trumpism-in-rural-us|title=A redneck revolt? Radical responses to Trumpism in the rural US|date=April 16, 2018|accessdate=August 18, 2018|work=[[openDemocracy]]|first=Levi|last=Van Sant}} The John Brown Gun Club sought to "demystify" firearms, and to distinguish their commitment to community self-defense from clandestine groups that advocated [[guerrilla warfare]].{{sfn|Van Sant|2018|p=1}} Its first major mobilization was a protest against the 2005 national conference of the [[Minuteman Project]].{{sfn|Van Sant|2018|p=2}} Following a hiatus the group was re-formed as a national organization in summer 2016,{{sfn|Bray|2017|p=119}}{{sfn|Van Sant|2018|p=1}} using both the Redneck Revolt and John Brown Gun Club names, with the intention of responding to the growth of [[right-wing populism]], particularly among rural, working-class white people.{{sfn|Van Sant|2018|p=1}} The group attributes their use of the word "[[redneck]]" to the time of the [[Coal Wars]], a series of labor disputes in the United States occurring from around 1890 to around 1930, when the word became popular among coalminers. The use of the term is also intended as a form of subversion or [[reappropriation]]. The group's name also refers to the 1921 [[Battle of Blair Mountain]], and the red bandanas worn by members emulate those worn by striking coalminers during that conflict.{{cite web|first=Stephen|last=Lemons|title=Lemons: Lefties with Guns Ready to Rumble with Right-Wing Militias, Says Arizona Anarchist|work=[[Phoenix New Times]]|date=April 5, 2017|accessdate=July 19, 2017|url=http://www.phoenixnewtimes.com/news/lefties-with-guns-ready-to-ruimble-with-right-wing-militias-says-arizona-anarchist-beth-payne-9221311}} A member has said that the group tries "to acknowledge the ways we've made mistakes and bought into [[white supremacy]] and [[capitalism]], but also give ourselves an environment in which it's OK to celebrate redneck culture". Their political influences include the 19th-century abolitionist [[John Brown (abolitionist)|John Brown]], the [[Young Patriots Organization]]{{sfn|Bray|2017|p=119}}{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/redneck-revolt-group-who-are-they-left-wing-armed-group-protect-minorities-interview-a8117551.html|title=Meet Redneck Revolt, the radical leftist group arming working-class people so they can defend minorities|date=December 25, 2017|accessdate=August 9, 2018|work=[[The Independent]]|first=Emily|last=Shugerman}} the [[Deacons for Defense and Justice]], and the [[Rainbow Coalition (Fred Hampton)|Rainbow Coalition]], an alliance formed in [[Chicago]] in the 1960s between the [[Black Panther Party]], [[Young Lords]] and the Young Patriots. The group sees itself as part of a tradition of white working-class "rebellion against tyranny and oppression". ==Views== {{quote box|title=Core principles of Redneck Revolt{{sfn|Van Sant|2018|p=3}}{{cite web|url=https://www.redneckrevolt.org/principles|title=Redneck Revolt organizing principles|accessdate=August 21, 2018|publisher=Redneck Revolt}}|quote={{ulist | We stand against white supremacy | We believe in true liberty for all people | We stand for organized defense of our communities | We are working class and poor people | We are an aboveground militant formation | We stand against the nation-state and its forces which protect the bosses and the rich (police and military) | We stand against capitalism | We stand against the wars of the rich | We stand against patriarchy | We believe in the right of militant resistance | We believe in the need for revolution }}}} Redneck Revolt is an [[anti-capitalist]],{{cite web|first=Jared|last=Ware|title=Redneck Revolt builds anti-racist, anti-capitalist movement with working class whites|work=[[ShadowProof]]|date=June 20, 2017|accessdate=July 18, 2017|url=https://shadowproof.com/2017/06/20/redneck-revolt-builds-anti-racist-anti-capitalist-movement-working-class-whites/}} [[anti-racist]] and [[anti-fascist]] group,{{cite book|first=Mark|last=Bray|title=[[Antifa: The Anti-Fascist Handbook]]|publisher=[[Melville House Publishing]]|year=2017|page=119|ref=harv}}{{cite web|first=Wes|last=Enzinna|title=The Long History of 'Nazi Punching'|work=[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]|date=January 26, 2017|accessdate=July 19, 2017|url=https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2017/01/video-richard-spencer-punch-antifa-fascism/}} and uses [[direct action]] tactics.{{cite web|first=David|last=Love|title=Pro-Gun, Pro-Labor and Anti-Racist, Redneck Revolt Is Trying to Steer Whites Away from Trump, Right-Wing Militias|date=July 19, 2017|accessdate=July 19, 2017|work=Atlanta Black Star|url=http://atlantablackstar.com/2017/07/19/pro-gun-pro-labor-and-anti-racist-redneck-revolt-is-trying-to-steer-whites-away-from-trump-right-wing-militias/}} Redneck Revolt supports the rights of [[Muslim]]s, immigrants and [[LGBT]] people and is opposed to [[economic inequality]]. Members also support the [[Black Lives Matter]] movement. The group's website includes statements in opposition to capitalism, the [[nation state]], white supremacy and "the wars of the rich", and advocates a "right of militant resistance". They advance a critique of white supremacy, which they describe as "a system of violence and power that ensures that political, economic, and social power is withheld from people who aren't white."{{sfn|Van Sant|2018|p=2}} They describe their purpose as to
incite a movement amongst working people that works toward the total liberation of all working people, regardless of skin color, religious background, sexual orientation, gender, country of birth, or any other division that bosses and politicians have used to fragment movements for social, political, and economic freedom.{{sfn|Van Sant|2018|p=2}}
The website also argues for the necessity of [[revolution]]. A spokesperson for the [[Phoenix, Arizona]] John Brown Gun Club said in April 2017 that the group includes [[anarchist]]s, [[communist]]s, [[libertarian]]s and [[Republican Party (United States)|Republicans]]. The group does not identify itself as part of the [[political left]], nor as politically [[Modern liberalism in the United States|liberal]]. The geographer Levi van Sant has argued that the group's ideology is a form of [[libertarian socialism]].{{sfn|Van Sant|2018|p=2}} The group also do not consider themselves part of [[Antifa (United States)|Antifa]]: though their goals are similar, Redneck Revolt members do not cover their faces and seek to be "as upfront about who [they] are and what [they]'re doing as possible."{{sfn|Bray|2017|p=120}} Redneck Revolt does [[Leaderless resistance|not have leaders]], and does not offer a detailed blueprint for political action: a spokesperson said in June 2017 that "We don't have some grand plan for how we want to remake the world. We're tackling a specific problem, which is white supremacy, which we find to be built into capitalism". The group supports [[Gun politics in the United States|gun rights]] and runs firearms training events. Members often view the practice of [[open carry|openly carrying]] guns as a political statement that intimidates opponents and affirms gun rights. In a May 2017 interview a member said the group uses guns only in self-defense and in "response to a rise in politically motivated violence and intimidation against vulnerable communities".{{cite web|first=Joshua|last=Hersh|title=Extremism experts are starting to worry about the left|work=[[Vice (magazine)|Vice]]|date=June 15, 2017|accessdate=July 18, 2017|url=https://news.vice.com/story/extremism-experts-are-starting-to-worry-about-the-left}} In September 2017 a member said "It's not about seizing the [[gun culture in the United States|gun culture]] or becoming obsessed about guns. It's only recognizing it's useful to know how to [[wikt:field strip|field strip]] and clean a rifle as much as it is to know how to fix wiring in your house and use a circular saw."{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldsun.com/news/local/counties/durham-county/article170840742.html|title=They're leftists with guns. Meet the Redneck Revolt|date=September 1, 2017|accessdate=September 20, 2017|work=[[The Herald-Sun (Durham, North Carolina)|The Herald-Sun]]|first=Virginia|last=Bridges}} The increased visibility of Redneck Revolt in 2017 has sparked debate among activists over the effects of armed protest and the possibility that the use of guns may lead to heightened violence. A member said in May 2017 that Redneck Revolt had reached out to groups such as the [[3 Percenters]], a predominantly right-wing group, with whom they have some common ground. The practice of openly carrying firearms, and a shared interest in guns, has led to dialogs with right-wing [[militia organizations in the United States|militias]]. Van Sant wrote in March 2018 that "Through patient dialogue and popular education, several Redneck Revolt chapters have been able to challenge the [[white nationalist]] ideologies of these [[right-wing libertarian]] militias and flip them away from anti-immigrant and pro-capitalist positions."{{sfn|Van Sant|2018|p=2}} The group argues that the white working-class have more in common with working-class [[people of color]] than with the wealthy. Dave Strano, a founding member, has argued that
The history of the white [[Working class in the United States|working class]] has been a history of being an exploited people. However, we've been an exploited people that further exploits other exploited people. While we've been living in tenements and slums for centuries, we've also been used by the rich to attack our neighbors, coworkers, and friends of different colors, religions and nationalities.
==Activities== ===Overview=== Redneck Revolt is a national network. Local groups use both the Redneck Revolt and John Brown Gun Club names. There is no official count of the number of chapters,{{cite web|url=https://www.csindy.com/coloradosprings/the-lefts-answer-to-emboldened-white-supremacists-a-militia-of-their-own/Content?oid=7441640|title=The left's answer to emboldened white supremacists? A militia of their own|date=September 27, 2017|accessdate=September 29, 2017|work=[[Colorado Springs Independent]]|first=Nat|last=Stein}} but as of December 2017 the group had around 45 such local chapters across more than 30 U.S. states.{{cite web|url=https://www.newsweek.com/redneck-revolt-left-wing-activists-protect-minorities-guns-760923|title=What is Redneck Revolt? These left-wing activists protest minorities with guns|date=December 27, 2017|accessdate=August 9, 2018|work=[[Newsweek]]|first=Cristina|last=Maza}} The group's membership grew during the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 presidential election]] and following the August 2017 [[Unite the Right rally]] in [[Charlottesville, Virginia]]. In 2018 local groups in [[Shelby, North Carolina]], [[Portland, Oregon]], and [[Asheville, North Carolina|Asheville]] and [[Boone, North Carolina]] disaffiliated from the national network. The group focuses on anti-racist organizing among white poor and working-class people, though members are not exclusively white: around 30 percent are people of color.{{sfn|Bray|2017|p=120}} In May 2018, a member said that at least one third of the group's membership were women, people of color or [[non-binary]] people. Speaking to Mark Bray, author of ''[[Antifa: The Anti-Fascist Handbook]]'', one of Redneck Revolt's co-founders said the group's membership includes veterans, former Republicans, and former members of the 3 Percenters.{{sfn|Bray|2017|p=120}} Redneck Revolt is active in spaces in which white supremacist groups also often recruit, including [[country music]] concerts, [[flea market]]s, gun shows, [[NASCAR]] events, [[rodeo]]s and [[state fair]]s.{{sfn|Van Sant|2018|p=2}} Chapters provide firearms and first aid training,{{cite web|url=https://mountainx.com/news/local-activists-strive-for-social-change/|title=Local activists strive for social change|date=November 10, 2017|accessdate=August 9, 2018|work=[[Mountain Xpress]]|first=Max|last=Hunt}} food and clothing programs, and [[community gardening in the United States|community gardens]], and host [[needle exchange]]s, [[potluck]]s, and educational events. In a September 2017 interview a member said that the group was exploring ways to respond to health care challenges and food shortages. Some of the group's activities are modeled after the [[Survival Programs]] pursued by the Black Panther Party and Young Patriots Organization in the 1960s. ===2016–17=== During the [[Dakota Access Pipeline protests]] in 2016 Redneck Revolt published a pamphlet addressed to members of right-wing militias that argued there was no reason why "the white working-class … [should] find solidarity with rich white ranch owners against the government, but not working-class people of color defending their own land and community." The [[Phoenix, Arizona]] chapter of Redneck Revolt openly carried firearms outside of the [[Arizona State Legislature]] on the day of the [[inauguration of Donald Trump]] in January 2017. They declared support for those opposing Trump, including immigrants, [[LGBTQ]] people and Muslims. In April 2017 members attended a counter-protest against groups including the [[League of the South]], the [[Traditionalist Worker's Party]] and the [[National Socialist Movement (United States)|National Socialist Movement]] in [[Pikeville, Kentucky]]. Later in April members hosted a barbecue in [[Harrisburg, Pennsylvania]], where Trump was marking his [[first 100 days of Donald Trump's presidency|100th day in office]].{{cite web|first=Cecilia Saixue|last=Watt|title=Redneck Revolt: the armed leftwing group that wants to stamp out fascism|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=July 11, 2017|accessdate=July 18, 2017|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/jul/11/redneck-revolt-guns-anti-racism-fascism-far-left}} Silver Valley Redneck Revolt, a local chapter, organized a counter-demonstration against a [[Ku Klux Klan]] rally in [[Asheboro, North Carolina]] in May 2017.{{cite web|first=Judi|last=Brinegar|title=Rallies against KKK find support|work=[[The Courier-Tribune]]|date=May 6, 2017|accessdate=July 19, 2017|url=http://www.courier-tribune.com/news/20170506/rallies-against-kkk-find-support}}{{cite web|first=Jordan|last=Green|title=Militant anti-Klan protesters march through downtown Asheboro|work=Triad City Beat|date=May 6, 2017|accessdate=July 19, 2017|url=https://triad-city-beat.com/militant-anti-klan-protesters-march-downtown-asheboro/}} In a [[Facebook]] post the group said "We need to let the Klan know that if they leave their enclaves there will be a broad response from the community ... This event is to publicly denounce the Klan, their beliefs, and show that we will not back down."{{cite web|first=Chip|last=Womick|title=Asheboro mayor to KKK: 'Don’t come here'|date=March 13, 2017|accessdate=July 19, 2017|work=[[The Courier-Tribune]]|url=http://www.courier-tribune.com/news/20170313/asheboro-mayor-to-kkk-dont-come-here}} A local chapter of Redneck Revolt was part of a counter-protest against a June 2017 rally in support of Trump in [[Portland, Oregon]].{{cite web|first=Madison|last=Pauly|title=A New Wave of Left-Wing Militants Is Ready to Rumble in Portland—and Beyond|work=[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]|date=May–June 2017|accessdate=July 18, 2017|url=https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2017/06/antifa-movement-anti-trump-politics-nazi/}} Also in June, members were part of a protest against the Christian conservative organization [[Focus on the Family]] in [[Colorado Springs, Colorado]], which coincided with a speech by [[Mike Pence]] to celebrate the group's fortieth anniversary.{{cite web|first=Julia|last=Trowbridge|title=VP Mike Pence speaks at Focus on the Family's 40th anniversary celebration|date=June 23, 2017|accessdate=July 19, 2017|work=[[Rocky Mountain Collegian]]|url=https://collegian.com/2017/06/vp-mike-pence-speaks-at-focus-on-the-familys-40th-anniversary-celebration/}} On June 23 armed members of Redneck Revolt attended a protest in [[Kalkaska, Michigan]] in response to anti-Muslim comments made by Jeff Sieting, the village president. Members carried a banner in support of Muslims and said they were there to protect the protesters from counter-protesters supporting Sieting.{{cite web|first1=Morgan|last1=Springer|first2=Daniel|last2=Wanschura|title=Kalkaska protesters argue about hate and freedom of speech in response to FB posts|publisher=[[Interlochen Public Radio]]|date=June 24, 2017|accessdate=July 19, 2017|url=http://interlochenpublicradio.org/post/kalkaska-protesters-argue-about-hate-and-freedom-speech-response-fb-posts}}{{cite web|url=https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/mbk5qx/kalkaska-michigan-islamophobic-mayor-defeated|title=How This Small Town in Trump Country Dumped Its Islamophobic President|date=June 8, 2018|accessdate=August 18, 2018|work=[[Vice (magazine)|Vice]]|first=Trevor|last=Bach}} In August 2017, members participated in protests against Trump's speech in Phoenix, Arizona.{{sfn|Bray|2017|p=120}}{{cite web|url=http://www.fox5ny.com/news/275454084-story|title=Trump opponents show up with rifles near event|date=August 22, 2017|accessdate=August 24, 2017|publisher=[[Fox 5 New York]]}}{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/trump-rally-protests-smoke-grenades-guns-phoenix-arizona-charlottesville-a7907651.html|title=Police deploy gas and pepper spray to disperse protesters outside Trump rally as thousands gather|date=August 23, 2017|accessdate=August 24, 2017|work=[[The Independent]]}} In February 2018 Dwayne E. Dixon, a member of Redneck Revolt and a teaching assistant professor at the [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]], was found not guilty of [[misdemeanour]] gun charges for his role in a protest against a Ku Klux Klan event in [[Durham, North Carolina]] the previous August.{{cite web |last=Wyllie |first=Julian |date=May 28, 2018 |title=A Professor Brought His Guns to Protect Protesters at White-Supremacist Rallies. Then His Troubles Started. |work=[[The Chronicle of Higher Education]] |url=https://www.chronicle.com/article/A-Professor-Brought-His-Guns/243516 |accessdate=August 20, 2018|url-access=subscription}}{{cite web|url=https://www.indyweek.com/news/archives/2018/02/09/charges-dropped-against-two-accused-of-bringing-weapons-to-anti-klan-rally|title=Charges Dropped Against Two Accused of Bringing Weapons to Anti-Klan Rally|date=February 9, 2018|accessdate=August 20, 2018|work=[[Indy Week]]|first=Sarah|last=Willets}} In September 2017, Redneck Revolt supported the [[Juggalo March on Washington]], a protest by [[juggalos]] against their designation as a [[Juggalo gangs|gang]]. Redneck Revolt's statement said the march aligned with their "belief in the right to community self-determination and self-defense".{{cite web|url=https://noisey.vice.com/en_us/article/gy5bjx/the-radical-politics-behind-the-juggalo-march-on-washington|title=The Radical Politics Behind the Juggalo March on Washington|date=September 14, 2017|accessdate=September 16, 2017|work=[[Vice (magazine)|Vice]]|first=Kitty|last=Stryker}} In October 2017 a branch of Redneck Revolt in [[Suffolk County, New York]] was involved in organizing a [[candlelight vigil]] for people suffering from [[opioid addiction]] and families effected by the [[opioid epidemic]].{{cite web|url=https://riverheadlocal.com/2017/09/30/candlelight-vigil-victims-opioid-epidemic-will-held-sunday-downtown-riverhead/|title=Candlelight vigil for victims of opioid epidemic will be held Sunday downtown|date=September 30, 2017|accessdate=October 12, 2017|work=Riverhead Local|first=Katie|last=Blasl}} ===Unite the Right rally=== At the [[Unite the Right rally]] in [[Charlottesville, Virginia]] on August 11 and 12, 2017, several Redneck Revolt chapters provided armed security and medical assistance for counterprotesters.{{cite web|url=https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2017/08/right-to-carry-laws-are-making-violent-protests-like-charlottesville-even-harder-to-defuse/|title=Right-to-Carry Laws Are Making Violent Protests Dispatch (Lexington)|The Dispatch]]|first=Ben|last=Coley}}{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/14/us/who-were-the-counterprotesters-in-charlottesville.html |title=Who Were the Counterprotesters in Charlottesville? |author=Farah Stockman |date=August 14, 2017 |work=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=August 17, 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theroot.com/the-caucasian-panthers-meet-the-rednecks-armed-ready-1821943540|title=The Caucasian Panthers: Meet the Rednecks Armed, Ready and 'Bout That Anti-Racist Life|date=January 12, 2018|accessdate=August 17, 2018|work=[[The Root (magazine)|The Root]]|first=Michael|last=Harriot}}{{cite Charlottesville|date=June 12, 2018|accessdate=August 21, 2018|work=[[The Intercept]]|first=Johnny|last=Dwyer}} Days later, members provided security at a "Hate Is Not Welcome in Lane County" march in [[Eugene, Oregon]] in response to the events in Charlottesville.{{cite 2017|work=[[Eugene Weekly]]|first=Carl|last=Segerstrom}} In October 2017, Redneck Revolt was one of a number of groups named as a defendant in a lawsuit filed on behalf of the city of Charlottesville and several Charlottesville-based businesses and [[neighborhood association]]s, which sought to prevent prohibit militia and [[paramilitary]] activity in Virginia.{{cite web|url=http://www.c-ville.com/militia/|title=Militia madness: City files suit against August 12 participants|date=October 12, 2017|accessdate=October 14, 2017|work=C-VILLE Weekly|first=Samantha|last=Baars}}{{cite web|url=http://www.dailyprogress.com/news/local/new-suits-filed-against-aug-rally-organizers/article_3053319a-af09-11e7-8f08-cf9467939c45.html|title=New suits filed against Aug. 12 rally organizers|date=October 12, 2017|accessdate=October 14, 2017|work=[[The Daily Progress]]|first=Chris|last=Suarez}}{{cite web|url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/03/league-south-banned-charlottesville-fallout-180327110755551.html|title=League of the South: No more armed rallies in Charlottesville|date=March 27, 2018|accessdate=August 17, 2018|work=[[Al Jazeera]]}}{{cite web|url=https://truthout.org/articles/why-is-charlottesville-suing-two-anti-racist-groups-over-last-years-violent-unite-the-right-rally/|title=Why Is Charlottesville Suing Two Anti-Racist Groups Over Last Year's Violent 'Unite the Right' Rally?|date=April 29, 2018|accessdate=August 18, 2018|work=[[Truthout]]|first=Michael|last=Arria}} The groups and individuals named as defendants, which also included the white supremacist activist [[Jason Kessler]], were accused of unlawful paramilitary activity, falsely assuming the role of law enforcement officers, and being a [[public nuisance]]. The lawsuit identified Redneck Revolt and the Socialist Rifle Association, an anti-fascist group that defends working-class people's right to bear arms, as "private militia groups ... [that] helped create and secure a staging area for counter-protestors." Mary McCord, a former federal prosecutor who played a leading role in the lawsuit, described the decision to include Redneck Revolt among the defendants as "painful" and said "This case was not conceived of because of Redneck Revolt, that's for sure. They fit the description, so it was pretty hard not to include them". In June 2018, a group of members of clergy asked the city and the other plaintiffs to remove Redneck Revolt from the complaint.{{cite web|url=https://www.dailyprogress.com/news/local/city/kessler-planning-anniversary-rallies-in-city-d-c/article_5039da00-6b7d-11e8-8545-3ff6606d0fa0.html|title=Kessler planning anniversary rallies in city, D.C.|date=June 8, 2018|accessdate=August 19, 2018|work=[[The Daily Progress]]|first=Chris|last=Suarez}} They argued that "There is a marked difference between the armed white supremacist groups who invaded Charlottesville with the intent to do harm and the armed anti-racist groups who came to Charlottesville to assist in supporting and protecting our most marginalized communities." A lead attorney for the plaintiffs responded that "The basis for this lawsuit is not about motives – it's about engaging in paramilitary activity. That's why Redneck Revolt was named as a defendant, and why they remain in the suit." Redneck Revolt and Kessler signed [[consent decree]]s to end paramilitary activity in Charlottesville to resolve the lawsuit when they were left as the only defendants in early July 2018.{{cite web|url=https://triad-city-beat.com/jason-kessler-redneck-revolt-settle-lawsuit-with-charlottesville/|title=Jason Kessler, Redneck Revolt settle lawsuit with Charlottesville|date=July 12, 2018|accessdate=August 21, 2018|work=Triad City Beat|first=Jordan|last=Green}} The consent decree prohibits members from returning to Charlottesville "as part of a unit of two or more persons acting in concert while armed with a firearm, weapon, shield or any item whose purpose is to inflict bodily harm, at any demonstration, rally, protest or march." Redneck Revolt issued a statement saying that it had chosen to end the lawsuit and to "focus our energies on the many important fights ahead." ==Significance== The historian [[Noel Ignatiev]], in September 2017, expressed concern regarding Redneck Revolt's commitment to "defense of our communities". Ignatiev argued that "in this society those who share our material conditions, our neighbors, our family members, our friends, the people working alongside us, usually reflect which race they (and we) are assigned to", and contended that "The goal is not to defend the white community but to abolish it, and along with it all communities defined by racial preference or oppression." He also criticised the group for failing to challenge "institutions that reproduce white supremacy—neither the criminal justice system, nor the schools, nor employment discrimination, nor real estate lending and renting policies", and concluded that "white people organized as whites are dangerous to the working class and to humanity, and white people with guns organized as whites are doubly so—and this is true regardless of the intentions of the organizers."{{cite web|url=https://hardcrackers.com/rainbow-coalition-class-war/|title=Rainbow Coalition or Class War?|date=September 15, 2017|accessdate=August 21, 2018|work=Hard Crackers: Chronicles of Everyday Life|first=Noel|last=Ignatiev|authorlink=Noel Ignatiev}} [[Gabriel Kuhn]] responded to Ignatiev in a 2018 article. Kuhn argued that "organizations with the aim to primarily mobilize and organize among the white working class ... are mandatory if we don't want to simply abandon this part of the population and hand it to the right on a silver platter."{{cite journal|url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/2036210213|first=Gabriel|last=Kuhn|authorlink=Gabriel Kuhn|title=New Classes for a New Class Politics: An Appreciation of David Gilbert's Looking at the U.S. White Working Class Historically|journal=Turning the Tide|volume=30|issue=2|year=2018|page=6|url-access=subscription}} The geographer Levi van Sant argued in March 2018 that
the Redneck Revolt model of [[Libertarian socialism|Libertarian Socialism]] reveals important things, and should be an important part of the [[American Left|U.S. Left]]. Of particular importance is their [[Antonio Gramsci|Gramscian]] effort to read for the 'good sense in the common sense' of [[right-wing populism]] through radical and [[grassroots]] engagement.{{sfn|Van Sant|2018|p=3}}
Van Sant has also identified three lessons that Redneck Revolt offers to the American left: that working-class white people "are not inherently conservative"; that the group's success is drawn from their critique of [[Modern liberalism in the United States|modern American liberalism]], including on firearms issues; and that they do not employ the rhetoric of [[white privilege]], diversity or inclusion, but instead "position themselves as part of working class and white rural communities" and "act in solidarity with oppressed peoples." Van Sant concluded that "The case of Redneck Revolt suggests there are promising alternatives to Trumpism emanating from the U.S. countryside too often ignored by the U.S. left." ==See also== * [[Anti-Racist Action]], a network of anti-fascists and anti-racists in North America * [[Black Women's Defense League]], a self-defense organization based in Texas * [[Huey P.
